channel.title: WebMD Health
channel.description: WebMD Health - Trustworthy, Credible and Timely Health Information. The content of this feed is confidential and proprietary. It may not be distributed, copied or otherwise reproduced without express written permission from WebMD.

item.title: GA Governor To Investigate Toxic Air At Plants
item.description: Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp says he is working with government officials to investigate toxic air emissions from two medical sterilization plants in the state.

img.alt: photo of tower that emit ethylene oxide
img.title: GA Governor To Investigate Toxic Air At Plants

item.content:encoded: Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp says he is working with government officials to investigate toxic air emissions from two medical sterilization plants in the state.

item.title: 3-D Printers Might Someday Make Replacement Hearts
item.description: Researchers have developed a new bioprinting method capable of creating parts of the human heart out of collagen.

img.title: 3-D Printers Might Someday Make Replacement Hearts

item.content:encoded: Researchers have developed a new bioprinting method capable of creating parts of the human heart out of collagen.

item.title: Man Holds His Own Heart After Transplant Surgery
item.description: A hospital program lets people recovering from transplants hold their former heart in their hands while learning how to care for their new one.

img.alt: photo of man holding his own heart
img.title: Man Holds His Own Heart After Transplant Surgery

item.content:encoded: A hospital program lets people recovering from transplants hold their former heart in their hands while learning how to care for their new one.

item.title: Drug Duo May Be a Weapon Against a Common Leukemia
item.description: The phase 3 trial of more than 500 U.S. patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) found that a combination of rituximab and ibrutinib extended patient survival.

img.title: Drug Duo May Be a Weapon Against a Common Leukemia

item.content:encoded: The phase 3 trial of more than 500 U.S. patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) found that a combination of rituximab and ibrutinib extended patient survival.

item.title: Georgia City Pledges To Test Air for Toxic Gas
item.description: The city of Smyrna, GA has pledged to do independent air testing for a cancer-causing chemical released by a medical sterilizing plant there , which would make it one of just a handful of communities nationwide to have its air tested for ethylene oxide.

img.title: Georgia City Pledges To Test Air for Toxic Gas

item.content:encoded: The city of Smyrna, GA has pledged to do independent air testing for a cancer-causing chemical released by a medical sterilizing plant there , which would make it one of just a handful of communities nationwide to have its air tested for ethylene oxide.

item.title: Mild Head Injury Can Impair Your Sense of Smell
item.description: It's been known that such problems could occur after a major concussion. But this study found it's also true for minor concussions caused by accidents such as falling off a bike with a helmet on

img.title: Mild Head Injury Can Impair Your Sense of Smell

item.content:encoded: It's been known that such problems could occur after a major concussion. But this study found it's also true for minor concussions caused by accidents such as falling off a bike with a helmet on

item.title: Vitamin A Linked to Lower Odds of Common Skin Cancer
item.description: The study of around 125,000 Americans found that people with the highest intake of vitamin A lowered their risk of squamous cell skin cancer by around 15%

img.title: Vitamin A Linked to Lower Odds of Common Skin Cancer

item.content:encoded: The study of around 125,000 Americans found that people with the highest intake of vitamin A lowered their risk of squamous cell skin cancer by around 15%

item.title: Researchers Weigh Benefits, Risks of PPIs
item.description: PPIs, or proton pump inhibitors, are among the most common prescription drugs and are used to treat acid reflux, heartburn, indigestion, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and stomach ulcers.

img.title: Researchers Weigh Benefits, Risks of PPIs

item.content:encoded: PPIs, or proton pump inhibitors, are among the most common prescription drugs and are used to treat acid reflux, heartburn, indigestion, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and stomach ulcers.

item.title: More and More Seniors Are Binge Drinking
item.description: Among seniors, binges are most common in men and those who use cannabis, researchers found. Experts said the trend is troubling, because older people should actually be cutting back on alcohol.

img.title: More and More Seniors Are Binge Drinking

item.content:encoded: Among seniors, binges are most common in men and those who use cannabis, researchers found. Experts said the trend is troubling, because older people should actually be cutting back on alcohol.

item.title: Older Parents May Have Better Behaved Kids
item.description: The study found that kids with at least one older parent were less likely to be defiant rule-breakers or physically aggressive.

img.title: Older Parents May Have Better Behaved Kids

item.content:encoded: The study found that kids with at least one older parent were less likely to be defiant rule-breakers or physically aggressive.

item.title: What Are Nootropics or “Smart Drugs” or Cognitive Enhancers?
item.description: "Smart drugs" and supplements promise to boost your memory, concentration, and more. Here's what you should know about them.

img.title: What Are Nootropics or “Smart Drugs” or Cognitive Enhancers?

item.content:encoded: "Smart drugs" and supplements promise to boost your memory, concentration, and more. Here's what you should know about them.

item.title: Childhood Cancer Steals 11 Million Years of Life: Study
item.description: Children in the poorest countries accounted for 82% of years of healthy life lost (9.5 million years) worldwide due to cancer in 2017, according to the study.

img.title: Childhood Cancer Steals 11 Million Years of Life: Study

item.content:encoded: Children in the poorest countries accounted for 82% of years of healthy life lost (9.5 million years) worldwide due to cancer in 2017, according to the study.

item.title: Heartburn Drugs Might Bring Allergy Woes
item.description: The researchers noted that as few as six daily doses of anti-acid medication each year were linked to an increased need for allergy medication. The risk of needing allergy medication rose with more frequent use of acid-reducing drugs.

img.title: Heartburn Drugs Might Bring Allergy Woes

item.content:encoded: The researchers noted that as few as six daily doses of anti-acid medication each year were linked to an increased need for allergy medication. The risk of needing allergy medication rose with more frequent use of acid-reducing drugs.

item.title: Are Too Many Kids Prescribed Antihistamines?
item.description: Physicians are still more likely to recommend antihistamines for children under age 12 with colds, despite the fact that they provide little known benefit, the researchers from Rutgers University in New Jersey said.

img.title: Are Too Many Kids Prescribed Antihistamines?

item.content:encoded: Physicians are still more likely to recommend antihistamines for children under age 12 with colds, despite the fact that they provide little known benefit, the researchers from Rutgers University in New Jersey said.

item.title: Clogged Leg Arteries May Not Require Invasive Surgery
item.description: Researchers followed patients with critical limb ischemia, which is the most severe form of clogged leg arteries. It can lead to slow healing of leg wounds, gangrene and amputation.

img.title: Clogged Leg Arteries May Not Require Invasive Surgery

item.content:encoded: Researchers followed patients with critical limb ischemia, which is the most severe form of clogged leg arteries. It can lead to slow healing of leg wounds, gangrene and amputation.

item.title: U.S. News Releases 2019-2020 Top Hospitals List
item.description: The Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN, claimed the No. 1 spot in the annual honor roll of best hospitals published today by U.S. News & World Report.

img.title: U.S. News Releases 2019-2020 Top Hospitals List

item.content:encoded: The Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN, claimed the No. 1 spot in the annual honor roll of best hospitals published today by U.S. News & World Report.

item.title: High Levels of Estrogen in Womb Might Raise Autism Risk
item.description: Prior studies had already implicated higher uterine concentrations of male sex hormones -- androgens -- in increasing the odds for an autism spectrum disorder.

img.title: High Levels of Estrogen in Womb Might Raise Autism Risk

item.content:encoded: Prior studies had already implicated higher uterine concentrations of male sex hormones -- androgens -- in increasing the odds for an autism spectrum disorder.

item.title: Not Just One Reason Kids Don't Drink Enough Water
item.description: For many parents, getting their children to drink water is not only a challenge, it is an almost impossible task. This lack of water can have deep impacts on children.

img.title: Not Just One Reason Kids Don't Drink Enough Water

item.content:encoded: For many parents, getting their children to drink water is not only a challenge, it is an almost impossible task. This lack of water can have deep impacts on children.

item.title: Where Is Your Risk of Dying Greatest After Surgery?
item.description: Approximately 100 million adults aged 45 or older undergo noncardiac surgery worldwide every year, therefore an estimated 1.8 million people die of complications within 30 days

img.title: Where Is Your Risk of Dying Greatest After Surgery?

item.content:encoded: Approximately 100 million adults aged 45 or older undergo noncardiac surgery worldwide every year, therefore an estimated 1.8 million people die of complications within 30 days

item.title: Trying to Avoid a Second Stroke? Blood Pressure Control Is Key
item.description: If you've already had one stroke, your risk for another is much higher.

img.title: Trying to Avoid a Second Stroke? Blood Pressure Control Is Key

item.content:encoded: If you've already had one stroke, your risk for another is much higher.

item.title: Could Your Cellphone Charger Electrocute You?
item.description: The report describes instances of people who were accidentally electrocuted and burned by phone charging cords.

img.alt: photo of cord burn on neck
img.title: Could Your Cellphone Charger Electrocute You?

item.content:encoded: The report describes instances of people who were accidentally electrocuted and burned by phone charging cords.

item.title: Racial Disparity in Care Starts in NICU
item.description: In general, the review found, black preterm infants were most vulnerable: Hospitals with a high percentage of black preemies typically had lower-quality care and fewer nurses, versus those with a smaller percentage of black patients.

img.title: Racial Disparity in Care Starts in NICU

item.content:encoded: In general, the review found, black preterm infants were most vulnerable: Hospitals with a high percentage of black preemies typically had lower-quality care and fewer nurses, versus those with a smaller percentage of black patients.

item.title: Family Home, Football Field Most Dangerous Spots for Kids' Head Injuries
item.description: For older kids, football was the leading cause of traumatic brain injury -- involved in 14% of cases among 10- to 14-year-olds and 9% for 15- to 19-year-olds. Basketball was the second-leading cause in these age groups, at 6% and 5%, respectively.

img.title: Family Home, Football Field Most Dangerous Spots for Kids' Head Injuries

item.content:encoded: For older kids, football was the leading cause of traumatic brain injury -- involved in 14% of cases among 10- to 14-year-olds and 9%  for 15- to 19-year-olds. Basketball was the second-leading cause in these age groups, at 6% and 5%, respectively.

item.title: Mosquito-Borne Brain Infection Found in Florida
item.description: Only about seven human cases of the EEE virus reported in the US each year. However, about one-third of people who contract it die.

img.title: Mosquito-Borne Brain Infection Found in Florida

item.content:encoded: Only about seven human cases of the EEE virus reported in the US each year. However, about one-third of people who contract it die.

item.title: Recall: Taco Seasoning Over Salmonella Fears
item.description: One of the products was branded as Walmart’s in-house Great Value Mild Taco Seasoning Mix and the other as H-E-B Taco Seasoning Mix.

img.title: Recall: Taco Seasoning Over Salmonella Fears

item.content:encoded: One of the products was branded as Walmart’s in-house Great Value Mild Taco Seasoning Mix and the other as H-E-B Taco Seasoning Mix.

item.title: Can Your Smartphone Make You Fat?
item.description: Those who used their smartphone five or more hours a day increased their risk of obesity by 43%. Meanwhile, 26% of those who were overweight and 4.6% of those who were obese spent more than five hours a day on their smartphone.

img.title: Can Your Smartphone Make You Fat?

item.content:encoded: Those who used their smartphone five or more hours a day increased their risk of obesity by 43%. Meanwhile, 26% of those who were overweight and 4.6% of those who were obese spent more than five hours a day on their smartphone.

item.title: Sexting May Be Less Common Among Teens Than You Think
item.description: But most teens have never sent or received a sex text, the new study found. It focused on about 5,600 students in American middle and high schools, ages 12 to 17.

img.title: Sexting May Be Less Common Among Teens Than You Think

item.content:encoded: But most teens have never sent or received a sex text, the new study found. It focused on about 5,600 students in American middle and high schools, ages 12 to 17.

item.title: CRISPR to be Used to Fight a Type of Blindness
item.description: Even though they have normal eyes, patients with this type of blindness lack a gene that turns light into signals to the brain that enable sight, the Associated Press reported.

img.title: CRISPR to be Used to Fight a Type of Blindness

item.content:encoded: Even though they have normal eyes, patients with this type of blindness lack a gene that turns light into signals to the brain that enable sight, the Associated Press reported.

item.title: Veterans of Toxic Air Fight Vow to Help Others
item.description: Two activists from Illinois, who fought to close a medical sterilization plant in their hometown, gathered with Georgia residents this week to discuss ways to fight a similar plant in their backyards.

img.alt: photo of tower that emit ethylene oxide
img.title: Veterans of Toxic Air Fight Vow to Help Others

item.content:encoded: Two activists from Illinois, who fought to close a medical sterilization plant in their hometown, gathered with Georgia residents this week to discuss ways to fight a similar plant in their backyards.

item.title: Warm Bath Can Send You Off to a Sound Slumber
item.description: A properly heated bath or shower taken at the right time for as little as 10 minutes can have a positive impact on sleep.

img.alt: Woman with headphones taking bubble bath
img.title: Warm Bath Can Send You Off to a Sound Slumber

item.content:encoded: A properly heated bath or shower taken at the right time for as little as 10 minutes can have a positive impact on sleep.

item.title: BPA Replacement Chemical May Not Be Safer for Kids

img.title: BPA Replacement Chemical May Not Be Safer for Kids

item.content:encoded: In recent years companies have turned to substitutes and tout their products as "BPA-free."

item.title: Plant-Based Diet Helps Keep Diabetes at Bay
item.description: People who ate a mostly plant-based diet reduced their risk of diabetes by 23%, the study found.

img.title: Plant-Based Diet Helps Keep Diabetes at Bay

item.content:encoded: People who ate a mostly plant-based diet reduced their risk of diabetes by 23%, the study found.

item.title: Dirty Air Kills 30,000 Americans Each Year
item.description: For the year 2015, the researchers extrapolated that air pollution still caused nearly 16,000 deaths in women and 15,000 in men in the United States.

img.title: Dirty Air Kills 30,000 Americans Each Year

item.content:encoded: For the year 2015,  the researchers extrapolated that air pollution still caused nearly 16,000 deaths in women and 15,000 in men in the United States.

item.title: 'Good Death': Choosing How to Live and How to Die
item.description: Between 2009 and 2017, the most recent year for which statistics are available, 1,364 people in Washington had used the law to end their lives. Last year, in California, 337 people chose to die under the state’s End of Life Option Act.

img.title: 'Good Death': Choosing How to Live and How to Die

item.content:encoded: Between 2009 and 2017, the most recent year for which statistics are available, 1,364 people in Washington had used the law to end their lives. Last year, in California, 337 people chose to die under the state’s End of Life Option Act.

item.title: U.S. Fertility Rate At All-Time Low
item.description: A report released earlier this year by the National Center for Health Statistics said the 2017 U.S. fertility rate continued to fall below what's needed for the population to replace itself, CNN reported.

img.title: U.S. Fertility Rate At All-Time Low

item.content:encoded: A report released earlier this year by the National Center for Health Statistics said the 2017 U.S. fertility rate continued to fall below what's needed for the population to replace itself, CNN reported.

item.title: Textured Breast Implants Recalled for Cancer Risk
item.description: The FDA says the textured surface, unique to Allergan’s implants, are tied to 481 cases of breast implant-associated anaplastic large cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL), a type of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

img.title: Textured Breast Implants Recalled for Cancer Risk

item.content:encoded: The FDA says the textured surface, unique to Allergan’s implants, are tied to 481 cases of breast implant-associated anaplastic large cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL), a type of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

item.title: New Cholesterol Drugs' Cost Put Patients at Risk
item.description: Patients are 16% more likely to have a heart-related health crisis if their PCSK9 prescription is rejected than if it is covered and filled for a year, according to researchers.

img.title: New Cholesterol Drugs' Cost Put Patients at Risk

item.content:encoded: Patients are 16% more likely to have a heart-related health crisis if their PCSK9 prescription is rejected than if it is covered and filled for a year, according to researchers.

item.title: Waist Size Key to Health, Even Without Obesity
item.description: His study found that a large waist size -- about 35 inches or more -- significantly increased the risk of an early death for women over 49, even when they had a normal BMI.

img.alt: mid section view of a woman measuring her waist
img.title: Waist Size Key to Health, Even Without Obesity

item.content:encoded: His study found that a large waist size  -- about 35 inches or more -- significantly increased the risk of an early death for women over 49, even when they had a  normal BMI.

item.title: Climate Change Blamed for Deadly Fungus Risk
item.description: More than 30% of people with invasive C. auris infections die, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. There have been 685 confirmed cases and 30 probable cases in the United States since 2016.

img.title: Climate Change Blamed for Deadly Fungus Risk

item.content:encoded: More than 30% of people with invasive C. auris infections die, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. There have been 685 confirmed cases and 30 probable cases in the United States since 2016.

item.title: Recall: Baby Neck Supports for Suffocation Risk
item.description: Three customers have complained to Boppy that the product caused their child’s head to be pushed forward, chin to chest, but no injuries were reported.

img.title: Recall: Baby Neck Supports for Suffocation Risk

item.content:encoded: Three customers have complained to Boppy that the product caused their child’s head to be pushed forward, chin to chest, but no injuries were reported.

item.title: Residents, Leaders 'Shocked' by Toxic Air Report
item.description: On Friday, WebMD and Georgia Health News revealed that Georgia had three census tracts the EPA identified as having elevated cancer risks because of a toxic gas called ethylene oxide.

img.alt: photo of tower that emit ethylene oxide
img.title: Residents, Leaders 'Shocked' by Toxic Air Report

item.content:encoded: On Friday, WebMD and Georgia Health News revealed that Georgia had three census tracts the EPA identified as having elevated cancer risks because of a toxic gas called ethylene oxide.

item.title: Pro Baseball Players Live Longer, Healthier Lives
item.description: Athletes in Major League Baseball (MLB) tend to live about 24% longer than the average American guy, according to a century's worth of mortality rates among nearly 10,500 pro baseball players.

img.title: Pro Baseball Players Live Longer, Healthier Lives

item.content:encoded: Athletes in Major League Baseball (MLB) tend to live about 24% longer than the average American guy, according to a century's worth of mortality rates among nearly 10,500 pro baseball players.

item.title: Extreme Eating Could Be an Early Clue to Autism
item.description: A new study finds atypical eating behaviors -- such as hypersensitivity to food textures or pocketing food without swallowing -- in 70% of kids with autism. That's 15 times the rate typically found in children.

img.title: Extreme Eating Could Be an Early Clue to Autism

item.content:encoded: A new study finds atypical eating behaviors -- such as hypersensitivity to food textures or pocketing food without swallowing -- in 70% of kids with autism. That's 15 times the rate typically found in children.

item.title: Guns in Home, Greater Odds of Family Homicide
item.description: For each 10% jump in home ownership of guns, the risk of someone in the household being killed rises by 13%. The risk of a nonfamily member getting murdered is increased only 2% with gun ownership, researchers found.

img.title: Guns in Home, Greater Odds of Family Homicide

item.content:encoded: For each 10% jump in home ownership of guns, the risk of someone in the household being killed rises by 13%. The risk of a nonfamily member getting murdered is increased only 2% with gun ownership, researchers found.

item.title: Just How Effective Are ADHD Meds?
item.description: In addition to helping kids calm down and concentrate in school, the review also found that the drugs help children avoid a lot of long-term negative consequences associated with ADHD, including depression, substance abuse and even driving problems.

img.title: Just How Effective Are ADHD Meds?

item.content:encoded: In addition to helping kids calm down and concentrate in school, the review also found that the drugs help children avoid a lot of long-term negative consequences associated with ADHD, including depression, substance abuse and even driving problems.

item.title: Many Taking Antibiotics Without a Prescription
item.description: Yet a new study review suggests that's exactly what many Americans are doing: misusing "under-the-counter" or old leftover antibiotics to self-medicate without seeing a doctor or getting a prescription.

img.title: Many Taking Antibiotics Without a Prescription

item.content:encoded: Yet a new study review suggests that's exactly what many Americans are doing: misusing "under-the-counter" or old leftover antibiotics to self-medicate without seeing a doctor or getting a prescription.

item.title: Testosterone Therapy May Threaten the Heart
item.description: Those who took testosterone replacement therapy had a 21% higher risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attack, stroke or mini-stroke than those who did not take the therapy. That increased risk translated into 128 more cardiovascular events.

img.title: Testosterone Therapy May Threaten the Heart

item.content:encoded: Those who took testosterone replacement therapy had a 21% higher risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attack, stroke or mini-stroke than those who did not take the therapy. That increased risk translated into 128 more cardiovascular events.

item.title: Listeria Fears Prompt Target, Fresh Market Recalls
item.description: The products were sold at Target and Fresh Market stores, and include egg salad, tuna salad and lobster salad.

img.title: Listeria Fears Prompt Target, Fresh Market Recalls

item.content:encoded: The products were sold at Target and Fresh Market stores, and include egg salad, tuna salad and lobster salad.

item.title: Residents Unaware of Cancer-Causing Toxin in Air
item.description: Federal data show an increased cancer risk to neighborhoods across the country around plants that emit a gas called ethylene oxide, which is used to sterilize medical equipment.

img.title: Residents Unaware of Cancer-Causing Toxin in Air

item.content:encoded: Federal data show an increased cancer risk to neighborhoods across the country around plants that emit a gas called ethylene oxide, which is used to sterilize medical equipment.

item.title: Heat Bakes the Nation, Here Are Some Safety Tips
item.description: Across two-thirds of the United States, over 115 million Americans live where some level of heat alert is already in effect, and 290 million will see temperatures soar past 90 degrees at some point in the next week, USA Today reported Wednesday.

img.title: Heat Bakes the Nation, Here Are Some Safety Tips

item.content:encoded: Across two-thirds of the United States, over 115 million Americans live where some level of heat alert is already in effect, and 290 million will see temperatures soar past 90 degrees at some point in the next week, USA Today reported Wednesday.
